sentences: Living close to a lake means we have an abundant supply of water.
Each fall, leaves accumulate in our driveway.
Make sure your address is accurate before submitting your online order.
Having 8AM classes means I’m accustomed to getting up early.
When my grandmother died, I acquired her cookbook collection.
The defendant was adamant that he was innocent.
Our house isn’t big, but it’s adequate for the two of us.
The park is adjacent to the school.

definitions: To change something so it serves its purpose better.
sentences: The bike seat may be too high; you’ll probably need to adjust it.

definitions: Something that makes it easier to achieve success.
sentences: His height gives him an advantage in basketball.
My aunt is a major advocate for women’s’ rights.
I had an adverse reaction to my medication and had to stop taking it.
We should aggregate our resources to share them more easily.
The salesperson was very aggressive when trying to get us to buy the television.

definitions: To put aside for a specific purpose.
sentences: The village needs to allocate funds for building the new school.
If the ATM is broken, an alternative solution is to stop by the bank.

definitions: Someone who is inexperienced or not highly skilled in a particular area.
sentences: He’s an amateur soccer player and is still learning the rules of the game.

definitions: Having several potential meanings; unclear and difficult to understand.
sentences: When I asked the HR manager what my chances were of getting the job, she gave me a very ambiguous reply.
My son is very ambitious and hopes to be a millionaire by the time he’s thirty.

definitions: To change for the better; to improve.
sentences: I believe we should amend our country’s tax laws.
Our new apartment has ample space for the two of us.
The basketball player is the team’s best free thrower, so his missing both shots was an anomaly.
The annual company barbeque takes place every August.

definitions: To tease or be hostile towards a person or group.
sentences: The boy loves to antagonize his little sister by pulling her hair.
After she got grounded, the teenager had a bad attitude for the rest of the day.
Be sure to attribute credit to your sources when writing a research paper.

definitions: Based on a whim or random decision.
sentences: Flipping a coin is an arbitrary way to make a decision.
After you cross the bridge, there’s an arduous walk up the hill.
The mother assuaged her child’s fear of the dark.
I assumed he was rich because he worked as a lawyer.
She augments her regular salary by babysitting on the weekends.
A benefit of doing homework on Friday is that your weekend will be free.
Our neighbor berated us after we broke his window playing baseball.
The medal was bestowed upon him by the president.

definitions: To brag or talk with excessive pride.
sentences: He always boasts of his talents after he wins a game.

definitions: To help raise or increase something.
sentences: I gave him a pep talk to boost his self-esteem before his speech.
The brash man always asked inappropriate questions.
It will only have a brief meeting, so you’ll still have plenty of time for lunch.

definitions: Abrupt to the point of rudeness.
sentences: After being away for so long, I expected more than her brusque greeting.

definitions: A harsh, unpleasant mixture of noise.
sentences: The cuckoo clock shop lets off a cacophony every hour.
I wish they would cease arguing.
Every parent in our district censured the education cuts.

definitions: Arranged in order of time or date.
sentences: Put the historical events in chronological order to make them easier to study.

definitions: To make clear; to remove confusion.
sentences: I didn’t understand the instructions, so I asked the teacher to clarify them.
The people on the street eventually coalesced into a group.

definitions: To force someone to do something against their will.
sentences: The young boy was coerced into stealing by his friends.

definitions: Being aware or having knowledge of something.
sentences: Before mountain climbing, you need to be cognizant of the risks.
Water molecules show strong cohesion when they stick together.

definitions: To occur at the same time.
sentences: This year Thanksgiving coincided with my birthday.

definitions: To fall down or break down.
sentences: The old building finally collapsed, leaving nothing but a pile of rubble.

definitions: To hit one another with a forceful impact.
sentences: The two cars collided on the freeway.

definitions: Dedication to a cause or activity.
sentences: Joining a school play is a big commitment. You’ll need to practice every evening.

definitions: A group of people who live or work together.
sentences: The Chinese community in my city is hosting a New Year celebration next week.
The mountains concealed the ocean from view.
He believes women should be paid as much as men, and I concur.
The conflict between the two families has been going on for generations.
You should move your plant to a bigger pot, otherwise you’ll constrain its roots.
I spend a lot of time contemplating what career I want to have.
My neighbors have been continuously blasting their music since last night.
I told the employees that sales were down, but my boss contradicted me and said sales were actually up.

definitions: To give something (usually money or time) to a common fund or cause.
sentences: Every roommate contributes part of his paycheck to the grocery bill.
I’ve conveyed my interest in working for that company.
He always takes copious notes during class to study later on.
Although many employees left the company, the core leadership remained.
The rust corroded the paint on my car.
Trying to carry four grocery bags at once was very cumbersome.

definitions: The courses given by a school or program.
sentences: Our school needs to add more music courses to its curriculum.

definitions: Facts, statistics, or pieces of information.
sentences: The data from these graphs show that yearly temperatures are increasing.

definitions: To decline in health or excellence.
sentences: After the tree died, its wood began to decay.
He deceived me by pretending to be a millionaire.
The spy deciphered the secret code.
He made a declaration to the office that he was quitting.

definitions: 2. To deteriorate (especially in terms of health.)
sentences: 1.  I declined his offer of a ride home.
2. Her health has declined ever since she turned 70.

Let me demonstrate the proper way of throwing a football.

definitions: To state that something isn’t true.
sentences: He denied being the robber.
Your shopping sprees have depleted my savings.

definitions: To deliver and leave an item.
sentences: Please deposit your books in the bin outside the library.
Bravery is a desirable trait for firefighters to have.
I despise early morning classes.

The warning signs on the house deterred trespassers.
I decided to deviate from my normal route home and took a shortcut.
The coach devised a plan for winning the game.
The politician went into a diatribe against her opponent.

definitions: To wander from the main subject.
sentences: The teacher digressed from the lecture to discuss the weather.

definitions: A situation where one must choose between two difficult choices.
sentences: The student faced the dilemma of attending school sick or missing her exam.
Sprinkle baking soda on the carpet to diminish the stain.
I need to dispose of this trash.

definitions: Too large or small when compared to something else.
sentences: The piece of pie I received was disproportionately small.

definitions: To interrupt by causing a disturbance.
sentences: The protesters disrupted the politician’s speech.

Distribute the materials evenly among the class.
This city has a very diverse population.

definitions: To cause a change of course.

This prescription will ease your allergies.

Our team lost the match and was eliminated from the competition.
The elite detective team were also sent for when there were big crimes.
Her eloquent writing has gained her many fans.

definitions: To give special importance to when speaking or writing.
sentences: The teacher emphasized the due date of the project.

definitions: To suffer through something difficult with patience.
sentences: He has endured four knee operations so far.

The duchess is the epitome of class.

Try to get an estimate of the number of people attending the concert.

definitions: Facts or information that help prove or disprove something.
sentences: These fossils are evidence of evolution.

We may not be able to get in since that club is very exclusive.

definitions: Expert knowledge or skill in a particular field.
sentences: The surgeon’s expertise is knee surgeries.

The emails presented exposed the company’s corruption.

definitions: An act of making something longer.
sentences: If you’re sick on the day the paper is due, the teacher may give you an extension on the due date.
The dentist extracted one of my teeth.

definitions: A time when there is an extreme lack of food.
sentences: Millions of children in  Ethiopia died due to the famine there.
This study plan you made for me sounds feasible, even with my work schedule.
Remember that life is finite; you’re not immortal.

definitions: A feature that ruins the perfection of something.

The king decided to fortify the castle walls to protect them during attacks.

definitions: A skeletal structure designed to support something.

You must stop spending your money on frivolous purchases.

definitions: A purpose natural to a person or thing.
sentences: The function of petals is to attract insects to the plant.
Learning scales is fundamental to being a good piano player.

definitions: A space in between to objects.
sentences: Be careful to avoid the gap between the two steps.

definitions: Communication that is distorted and unclear.

definitions: To pause, often due to reluctance.
sentences: She hesitated before entering the abandoned building.

definitions: Something that causes delay or resistance.

definitions: An unproven idea that attempts to explain something.

definitions: To explain by using an example.

Even if you’re healthy, death is inevitable in the end.

definitions: The ability to have an impact of something.
sentences: The older sister has been a positive influence on her younger siblings.

definitions: An investigation to determine the truth.
sentences: Congress launched an inquiry after the senator was accused of taking bribes.

definitions: To explain the meaning of something.
sentences: I need you to interpret this German speech for me.

definitions: To come between people, objects, or an event and change what is happening.
sentences: When the toddlers couldn’t share their toys, their mothers had to intervene.

The pattern on this blanket is so intricate.

definitions: The use of words to give a meaning opposite to their literal meaning.
sentences: “I love spending my Friday nights doing homework,” she said with irony.

definitions: Words specific to a certain job or group.

definitions: To become weak; to be neglected.

definitions: A talk given to an audience.

definitions: To continue at the same level.

definitions: To influence, especially in an unfair way.
sentences: He tried to manipulate the results of the election.

definitions: To increase to the greatest possible size.
sentences: The store’s goal this year is to maximize its profit.

definitions: To find the size and dimensions of something.
sentences: By measuring the tree, I found it was seven feet tall.

definitions: To move from one place to another.
sentences: Every fall, the geese migrate to Florida.

definitions: The smallest or lowest amount possible.

definitions: Someone on the opposite side for a game or contest.

definitions: Something existing in very small amounts; scarcity.
sentences: During the drought, the town had a paucity of fresh water.

definitions: The highest or most important point.
sentences: Winning the championship was the peak of his career.

definitions: Located on the side or edge.

definitions: To continue, especially when facing opposition.
sentences: I may have lost my last six games, but I will continue to persist trying to win.

definitions: A period or stage in a process.

definitions: A record of opinions or votes.

definitions: To further to progress of something.

definitions: Disagreement or fight; to have an argument.

definitions: The distance between two things, often the maximum and the minimum.

definitions: To present someone with confidence and approval.
sentences: I need to ask Mr. Smith if he’ll recommend me for this leadership position.

definitions: To make changes that improve something.

definitions: To supervise or control a process so that it functions correctly.

definitions: To say no to something that is offered.

definitions: To free; to allow to be known.

definitions: To need for a specific purpose.

definitions: To feel bitterness or anger towards someone or something.

definitions: To give up an office or position.

definitions: To come to a firm decision.
sentences: Matt resolved to get better grades next semester by studying every night.

definitions: To confine or keep within limits.
sentences: My doctor told me to restrict myself to one glass of wine a day.

definitions: To continue to do something or keep something.
sentences: I’ve decided to retain my normal hairstyle.

definitions: 2. To withdraw something after it’s found to be untrue.
sentences: 1. I felt calmer after the lion retracted its claws.
2. After numerous errors were found, the newspaper retracted the story.

definitions: Used just for style or impact.

definitions: Something that serves as protection or ensures safety.

definitions: Things that follow each other in a certain order.

2. My uncle is currently battling a severe illness in the hospital.

definitions: A person, place, or thing where something was obtained.

definitions: To form a theory without strong evidence.

definitions: A plan to reach a desired outcome.
sentences: The football team will need a good strategy to win the game tomorrow.

definitions: A person or thing acting in place of another.

definitions: Enough to serve a particular purpose.
sentences: Make sure you have sufficient food for the camping trip.

definitions: To briefly give the main points.

definitions: To oversee work or a process.
sentences: My dad didn’t think we were old enough to build the fort on our own, so he supervised us.

definitions: To take the place of something else.

definitions: Having the belief that someone is doing something dishonest or illegal.
sentences: The couple became suspicious when they saw strange men removing their neighbor’s expensive electronics during the night.

definitions: Relating to a specific subject or craft.

definitions: To move from one place to another.
sentences: Ben’s work is going to transfer him from Chicago to Detroit.

definitions: Changing from one state or condition to another.

definitions: The fee for instruction at a school.

definitions: To be different from something else in a group.

definitions: A small trace of something that is disappearing or has already disappeared.

definitions: A small container used to hold liquids.
sentences: The chemist carefully filled the vial with the bubbling solution.

definitions: To speak poorly of; to slander.

definitions: Taking up a lot of space.
